intro: Bahiopsis similis, commonly known as the desert dandelion, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble a single flower. The plant typically grows from 10 to 30 centimeters tall, with hairy, gray-green leaves that help reduce water loss in hot, dry environments. Its yellow flowers bloom in spring, producing small, wind-dispersed seeds. Bahiopsis similis is well adapted to harsh desert conditions, making it a resilient and drought-tolerant species.
